And he was excited to see how the world could progress in the future, with breathtaking architecture and stunning technological advancements that were beyond his wildest dreams.", "Sure, here's an edited version of the story with more details about the hovercars:

Jason had always been fascinated by the concept of time travel. So when his friend, a renowned scientist, offered him the chance to be a part of a groundbreaking experiment, he didn't hesitate to agree. Jason was to be the first person to travel to the future.

The day of the experiment arrived, and Jason was filled with excitement and nervousness. He stepped into the time machine, and the scientist set the coordinates to 100 years into the future. The machine hummed to life, and everything around Jason started to blur.

When the blurriness subsided, Jason found himself standing in the middle of a bustling city. It was nothing like the cities he was used to. The buildings towered high into the sky, with shining glass and steel structures stretching as far as the eye could see. The city was alive with energy, with sleek hovercars whizzing by and people rushing around on foot.

Jason was struck by the incredible variety of architectural styles on display. Some buildings were completely covered in vines and gardens, while others had sleek, geometric designs that seemed to defy gravity. There were towering skyscrapers that soared toward the clouds, as well as smaller, quirky buildings that looked like something straight out of a science fiction movie.

As he continued to explore, Jason couldn't help but be fascinated by the hovercars that zoomed by. These sleek vehicles were unlike anything he had ever seen before. They were long and slim, with aerodynamic designs that allowed them to fly through the air with ease. The cars were made of high-tech materials that shimmered in the sunlight, and they were powered by an energy source that Jason couldn't even begin to comprehend.

The cars moved smoothly through the air, without a sound or a hint of exhaust. They were controlled by an advanced system that allowed them to travel at incredible speeds, weaving in and out of traffic like graceful birds in flight. People seemed to use them for everything, from commuting to work to taking a leisurely joyride through the city.

Jason marvelled at the technological advancements that had been made in the past century. He had never seen anything like these hovercars, and he couldn't wait to learn more about them. As he continued to explore the fascinating world of the future, he felt a sense of wonder and amazement that he knew he would never forget."]

prompt_en: ['Provide a comprehensive guide on how to create a successful mobile app marketing campaign, which includes step-by-step instructions on setting marketing goals, identifying target audience, creating compelling content, selecting appropriate marketing channels, analyzing metrics, and optimizing the campaign for maximum reach and engagement. Please include tips on creating visually appealing ads, crafting impactful app descriptions, integrating social media strategies, and securing positive reviews and ratings. Additionally, please provide real-life examples of successful mobile app marketing campaigns and the tactics used to achieve their goals.', 'Thanks for the comprehensive guide on how to create a successful mobile app marketing campaign. Can you please provide some more information on how to effectively use email marketing as a marketing channel? Also, how can we ensure that our email campaigns are not marked as spam by users?']
response_en:
["Creating a successful mobile app marketing campaign can be challenging, but following these steps can significantly increase your chances of success.

Step 1: Set marketing goals
The first step in creating a successful mobile app marketing campaign is to set clear marketing goals. Identify the purpose of your campaign, whether it is to increase app downloads, improve user retention, increase revenue, or something else. Your marketing goals will determine the tactics you will use in your campaign.

Step 2: Identify target audience
Knowing your target audience is crucial in creating a successful mobile app marketing campaign. Identify who your app is designed for and what type of users are most likely to use it. Research their interests, behaviors, demographics, and pain points to ensure your messaging and targeting are relevant.

Step 3: Create compelling content
Compelling content is critical to grabbing users' attention and driving engagement. Create visually appealing app screenshots, videos, and descriptions that showcase the app's unique features and benefits. Keep your messaging concise and focused on the user's needs.

Step 4: Select appropriate marketing channels
Choose the marketing channels that are most effective in reaching your target audience. These channels could include app store optimization, social media marketing, influencer marketing, email marketing, paid advertising, or a combination of these channels.

Step 5: Analyze metrics
Measuring and analyzing metrics is essential to evaluating your marketing campaign's performance. Track metrics such as app downloads, user retention, engagement, revenue, and user feedback to assess the effectiveness of your tactics.

Step 6: Optimize the campaign
Use the insights gained from analyzing your metrics to optimize your campaign for maximum reach and engagement. Adjust your messaging, targeting, and tactics to improve performance continually.

Tips for creating visually appealing ads:
- Use high-quality images and videos that showcase your app's unique features and benefits.
- Keep your message concise and focused on the user's needs.
- Use fonts, colors, and design elements that align with your brand's identity.
- Test different ad formats to determine which ones perform best with your target audience.

Tips for crafting impactful app descriptions:
- Start with a clear and concise title that accurately reflects your app's purpose.
- Use bullet points to highlight your app's key features and benefits.
- Keep your description brief but informative.
- Use language that resonates with your target audience.

Tips for integrating social media strategies:
- Identify which social media platforms your target audience uses the most.
- Create engaging content that resonates with your audience and encourages them to share it.
- Use social media influencers to promote your app to a wider audience.
- Engage with your followers by responding to comments and messages promptly.

Tips for securing positive reviews and ratings:
- Encourage users to leave reviews and ratings by providing a seamless user experience and offering incentives.
- Respond promptly to negative reviews and work to address and resolve any issues.
- Incorporate user feedback into future updates to improve the app's functionality and user experience.

Real-life examples of successful mobile app marketing campaigns:
1. TikTok's #BacktoSchool campaign
TikTok launched a back-to-school marketing campaign to help students and parents prepare for the new school year. The campaign included a series of videos featuring popular creators and education influencers, providing tips on everything from meal planning to study tips. The campaign generated over 2.5 billion views and helped increase TikTok's user base.

2. Nike's Nike Training Club app campaign
Nike launched a marketing campaign to promote its Nike Training Club app. The campaign featured a series of workout videos and interactive experiences, highlighting the app's features and benefits. The campaign generated over 4 million app downloads and a significant increase in app engagement.

3. Headspace's meditation app campaign
Headspace launched a marketing campaign to promote its meditation app, targeting stressed-out urban dwellers. The campaign featured a series of clever billboards and video ads set in busy urban environments, encouraging users to take a break and meditate. The campaign generated over 11 million app downloads and helped establish Headspace as a leader in the mindfulness space.

In conclusion, creating a successful mobile app marketing campaign requires careful planning, clear goals, and a thorough understanding of your target audience. By following these steps and tips, you can create a compelling campaign that engages users and drives results.", 'Sure, here are some tips on how to effectively use email marketing as a marketing channel:

1. Build a quality email list
It is essential to have a quality email list to ensure that your message is delivered to the right audience. Avoid buying email lists or using harvested email addresses, as this can harm your email deliverability and reputation.

2. Personalize your emails
Personalization can significantly improve your email open rates and click-through rates. Use your subscriber's name in the email subject line and personalize the content to their interests or behavior.

3. Create engaging subject lines
Your subject line is the first thing that your subscribers will see, and it must be compelling enough to entice them to open your email. Use actionable language and avoid using words that can trigger spam filters.

4. Segment your email list
Segmenting your email list can help you deliver targeted messages to specific groups of subscribers. Segment your list based on subscriber behavior, interests, demographics, or other criteria that make sense for your campaign.

5. Optimize your email design
Ensure that your emails are mobile-friendly and optimized for various email clients. Use clear, concise messaging and visuals that create a cohesive brand experience.

6. Follow email marketing best practices
Following email marketing best practices can ensure that your email campaigns are successful, and subscribers are engaged. These include avoiding spam trigger words, including an unsubscribe link, avoiding using excessive punctuation or capitalized words, and ensuring that your email isn't too promotional.

Regarding avoiding being marked as spam by users, here are some tips:

1. Obtain permission
Ensure that you have obtained permission from your subscribers to send them marketing emails.

2. Use a reputable email service provider
Using a reputable email service provider can protect your email deliverability and ensure that your email reaches your subscriber's inbox.

3. Use a recognizable "From" name and email address
Using a recognizable "From" name and email address can help your subscribers recognize your emails and reduce the chances of them marking your emails as spam.

4. Avoid using spam trigger words
Avoid using words that can trigger Spam filters, such as "free," "discount," "opportunity," or "urgent." Keep your messaging clear and concise.

5. Include an unsubscribe link
Ensure that your email includes an unsubscribe link, allowing subscribers to opt-out of receiving future emails.

By following these tips, you can effectively use email marketing as a marketing channel while reducing the chances of being marked as spam by users.']

prompt_en:
['After all the knowledge and insights gained yesterday, I was hungry for more and day 2 didn’t disappoint me much. After settling with my usual cuppa coffee, I sat down for a keynote from David Fischer who is the VP of Advertising and Global Operations at Facebook (these designations keep on getting longer don’t they?). David started his keynote by saying that Facebook takes you from “what to the who”. David shared an interesting fact that Indian users of Facebook spend 3 hours/ month vs. 1hr 50 minutes/month spent on Google. Deciding to let that stat sink in, David then showed a hilarious clip of a person getting married and as soon as the priest says “I pronounce you husband and wife”, the man pulls out a mobile phone and changes his relationship status on Facebook to “married” (that’s really cute).
Many of us associate Facebook with being a way to find old friends and make new ones too. But some people have used Facebook for social causes as well. David speaks of an incident when Beth was desperately looking for a kidney donor & found an angel donor who was ready to give a kidney for someone that person barely knew. So in case you thought that Facebook was just fun and games, think again.
Coming back to the topic of discussion, David draws attention to the fact that although there are around 90 million active websites, there are 500 million FB profiles. This stat shows you how popular Facebook is and also its reach and power.
Although the Internet in India is growing at a rapid clip, the rise in the numbers of Indians using Facebook has caused Major Indian Companies and Brands to sit up and take notice. Already, websites of the major brands in India have started implementing Facebook’s social pluggins and hence integrating facebook with their websites. David shared a few example of brands and companies which are doing this well.
The Times of India (India’s largest newspaper publication) allows users to post comments using their FB logins.
Also Cricinfo (a popular cricket portal) saw their referral traffic double after implementing the FB share button on their website.
Economic times used Facebook to find out what questions people wanted to ask the finance minister regarding the Indian budget and received a phenomenal response.
Website Vs Facebook which one is more popular?
Wow I don’t know about you, but that was an eye opener for me. But there’s even more good stuff to follow in terms of case studies. Dig in!
Case Study – Amex using Facebook as a marketing platform. In the US they had an SME card that they wanted to market to the small business owners. Amex turned to FB where they took a day in November and called it “Small Business Saturday”. Amex backed this up with strong promotions and advertising through offline media and within 3 weeks they got 1.2 million connections. They backed this up with an offer & they were able to increase sales by 27% as a result of this campaign.
Closer to Home, Indian Telco Tata Indicom’s Facebook fan page has 300,000 fans and counting. David illustrated the benefit of all that fan power by saying that whenever Tata takes out an ad on FB, then people will be able to see if any of their friends like it or not. And according to research by Nielson, people are 68% more likely to click on such an ad ( with more social context) along with their purchasing intent going up by 4 times. This is because someone they trust has just endorsed the ad.
Sensing a few queries from the inquisitive members of the audience, David fielded a few questions.
Q>One member of the audience asked that if a company’s fan page has 100,000 fans and it posts an update, will it be visible to all the fans.
A>I found myself thinking, good luck to finding an answer to that mate, but David Fischer jumped in saying that it really depends on Facebook’s Edge Rank algorithm which ranks a story based on the number of interactions, time decay (as in how recent the update is) and other factors. Hmm.. I had just heard of the Edge rank recently at another social media event I attended so I smiled to myself while there was a buzz in the crowd as most had never heard of Edge rank.
A>David acknowledges that there are issues with fake profiles however they are not a major threat. He goes further to emphasize that there is a team at FB which looks at such problems and the team systematically deals with these types of black hat practices effectively.
Summing up this extremely interesting keynote, David spoke on how FB’s personality has always been an informal one and companies would so well to keep this in mind. In case your approach to a FB company account is taking a week to respond to comments after routing responses through legal, then that’s not the way Facebook works. David urged companies to put a 22 year old or a junior employee in charge of a company’s Facebook account since that person will generally be on Facebook most of the time and will understand the pulse of Facebook fans a lot better. I personally would agree and also emphasize that maintaining informality seems to be the key to establishing a strong connect with fans on Facebook. How have major Indian companies and brands started integrating Facebook with their websites and what are some examples of successful implementations?', 'Can you provide more examples of how Indian companies are using Facebook for marketing purposes?', "Can you summarize David Fischer's advice on how companies should approach their Facebook accounts?", 'Can you provide more insights on how Amex used Facebook as a marketing platform for their SME card in the US?']
response_en:
["Many major Indian companies and brands have started integrating Facebook with their websites by implementing Facebook's social plugins. For example, The Times of India allows users to post comments using their Facebook logins, Cricinfo saw their referral traffic double after implementing the Facebook share button, and Economic Times used Facebook to find out what questions people wanted to ask the finance minister regarding the Indian budget and received a phenomenal response. Indian Telco Tata Indicom's Facebook fan page has 300,000 fans and counting and they use their fan power to back up their ads, increasing their purchasing intent up to 4 times.", 'Sure, here are a few more examples of how Indian companies are using Facebook for marketing purposes:

1. Starbucks India created a Facebook campaign called "Meet me at Starbucks" which encouraged users to post photos of themselves enjoying a sip of coffee at one of the brand's stores. The campaign was a success and created a lot of buzz on social media.

2. Mahindra & Mahindra, an Indian multinational automobile manufacturing corporation, launched a Facebook campaign called "Live Young Live Free" which encouraged users to share stories and images of themselves living life to the fullest. The campaign received over 50,000 entries and helped the brand connect with its target audience in a meaningful way.

3. Airtel, one of India's leading telecom companies, created a Facebook campaign called "Har Ek Friend Zaroori Hota Hai" which played on the idea of friendship and encouraged users to share the campaign with their friends. The campaign was a huge success and helped the brand reach a wider audience.

4. Big Bazaar, a popular retail chain in India, created a Facebook campaign called "India's Most Fashionable Family" which encouraged users to upload photos of their family dressed in fashionable clothes. The campaign received over 1.5 million entries and helped the brand connect with its target audience in a unique way.', "David Fischer advises that companies should maintain an informal approach when managing their Facebook accounts. He suggests that a 22-year-old or a junior employee who is on Facebook most of the time should be in charge of managing the account since they will have a better understanding of the platform's pulse. Furthermore, companies should avoid responding to comments after routing them through legal and should respond promptly to their fans. Fischer also emphasizes that Facebook's personality has always been an informal one, and companies will do well to keep this in mind in their approach to Facebook. Additionally, companies should implement Facebook's social plugins into their websites and activate Facebook ads to target customers more effectively.", 'Certainly! Amex wanted to market their SME card to small business owners in the US and decided to use Facebook as a marketing platform. They created a campaign called "Small Business Saturday," where they encouraged people to shop at local small businesses on the Saturday after Thanksgiving. They promoted the campaign heavily through offline media, as well as through Facebook ads, and within three weeks they got 1.2 million connections. They backed this up with an offer, and they were able to increase sales by 27% as a result of this campaign. This case study highlights the power of Facebook as a marketing platform and how it can be used to drive sales and engagement with customers.']

prompt_en: ['Write a 5-7 minute sketch comedy script in a fast-paced, physical comedy style about a character who forgets their own birthday, and spends the entire day trying to avoid their well-meaning friends and family who are trying to surprise them with a party. Incorporate elements of slapstick humor, witty one-liners, and recurring gags throughout the sketch. Bonus points for a surprise twist ending that subverts audience expectations.', 'Oh wow, I love this script so far! This is exactly what I was looking for. Can you add some more physical comedy elements to it? Maybe something involving Lucas accidentally knocking things over or tripping?', 'Nice! I love the addition of physical comedy. But can we have some more recurring gags throughout the sketch? Maybe a running joke that Lucas says every time something goes wrong?']
response_en:
["Title: The Unbirthday 

FADE IN:

INT. BEDROOM – MORNING 

We see LUCAS (early 30s), a scruffy-looking guy waking up from his bed. He rubs his eyes and yawns. 

LUCAS 
(to himself) 

Ahh, it's my sweet sweet...weed-a-birthday? No, it's not today. 

Lucas checks the calendar hanging on his wall. It's marked with several red crosses. 

LUCAS (CONT'D) 

Why did I cross out so many dates? (pauses) Ahh, never mind. 

Suddenly, we hear a loud knock on the door. 

FAMILY (Offscreen) 

Happy birthday, Lucas! 

Lucas jumps out of bed and runs over to the door. 

LUCAS 

(to himself) 

What the hell? Did they just say birthday? 

Lucas takes a deep breath and slowly opens the door. 

FAMILY AND FRIENDS 

(Surprised) 

Surprise! 

Lucas stares at them, blankly. 

LUCAS 

Umm, hi...guys? 

FRIEND 

Dude, you look completely lost. You did remember it's your birthday today, right? 

LUCAS 
(awkwardly) 

Of course, I did. I was just, you know, catching up on some sleep. 

FAMILY 

(Cheering together) 

Yaaayy! 

Lucas starts to panic. He remembers that he didn't prepare for any party stuff like decorations, cake, etc. 

FADE OUT

FADE IN: 

INT. KITCHEN – AFTERNOON 

We see Lucas standing in the middle of the kitchen. He is wearing a tattered stained apron, and his hair is messed up. He is busy trying to make a cake from scratch by following a recipe book. Flour is all over the place, and the utensils look like they were thrown without any care. 

LUCAS 

(to himself) 

Oh, come on! Is this so damn difficult? 

As he's trying to add the sugar, the jar slips from his grip, and the sugar spills all over him. 

LUCAS (CONT'D) 

Crap! Now, I need a shower too. 

He takes off his apron and heads towards the bathroom. 

FADE OUT 

FADE IN: 

INT. LIVING ROOM - EVENING 

Lucas steps out of the bathroom, dressed up but looking a little disheveled. He checks the time on his phone. 

LUCAS 

(to himself) 

It's already 6 pm. The party must have started by now. 

He heads to the living room and peeks inside. The room is dark, and everyone seems to be hiding. 

LUCAS (CONT'D) 

(to himself) 

Wait a sec. Why is everything so silent, and my friends look like they're waiting to spring out of the darkness? 

Suddenly, the lights switch on, and everyone jumps out to surprise Lucas. 

FAMILY AND FRIENDS 

(Surprised) 

Happy Birthday, Lucas! 

Lucas screams, and jumps back, shattering a vase on the floor. 

LUCAS 

(SCREAMING) 

What the hell, guys? You almost gave me a heart attack. 

FAMILY 

(Laughing) 

We're sorry, man. We just wanted to surprise you. 

LUCAS 

(tensely) 

Yeah, I can see that. I need to relax a bit. 

As he begins to walk around the room, Lucas trips and falls, face-first, over the cake he made earlier. 

EVERYONE 

(Surprised) 

Oh no! 

FADE OUT 

FADE IN: 

INT. LIVING ROOM - LATER 

Lucas is lying on the couch with cake all over his face, and a bruised nose. 

LUCAS 

(GRUMBLING) 

I can't believe this day. My birthday turned out to be the worst day of my life. 

Suddenly, the doorbell rings. 

LUCAS (CONT'D) 

(to himself) 

Oh, come on. Who could it be now? 

Lucas walks to the door and opens it to see his EX-GIRLFRIEND (early 30s) standing there, holding a cake box. 

EX-GIRLFRIEND 

(Smiling) 

Surprise, Lucas! You never told me it was your birthday today. 

LUCAS 

(Surprised and Confused) 

Wait, what? You never told me either. 

EX-GIRLFRIEND 

(Cheerfully) 

Well, I came by last night while you were sleeping, and your family said they would keep the secret. 

LUCAS 

(Surprised and Awestruck) 

Oh god! I completely", "Sure, here's an updated version of the script with some more physical comedy elements:

(Cheerfully", "Absolutely, here's an updated version of the script with some recurring gags:

prompt_en: ['How do successful advocacy campaigns balance grassroots and top-down strategies?', "I'm really interested in learning how to balance grassroots and top-down strategies in advocacy campaigns. Do you have any specific examples of successful campaigns that have done this well?", "That's really interesting! I'm curious, do you have any tips on how to make grassroots efforts more effective?", "Wow, I didn't realize there were so many ways to make grassroots efforts effective. Do you think it's better to focus on one specific issue or to cover multiple issues in a grassroots campaign?"]
response_en:
['Successful advocacy campaigns balance grassroots and top-down strategies by integrating both approaches as a part of their overall strategy. Here are some ways how they do it:

1. Building Strong Grassroots Networks: Successful advocacy campaigns focus on building strong grassroots networks, which involve a community of people who are committed to the cause and can mobilize support for it. This is done by building relationships with local leaders and organizations, engaging with stakeholders at the community level, and making sure that the campaign is responsive to the needs and concerns of the local population.

2. Collaboration with Key Decision-Makers: Advocacy campaigns also focus on collaboration with key decision-makers at the top, such as policymakers, elected officials, and other influential individuals. This helps to amplify the impact of the campaign by leveraging the power and resources of those in positions of authority.

3. Tailored Messaging: Successful advocacy campaigns tailor their messaging to appeal to both grassroots and top-down audiences. This means that they use language, examples, and messaging that resonates with each group in a meaningful way.

4. Creative Tactics: Successful advocacy campaigns use creative tactics that capture the attention of both grassroots and top-down audiences. This could include things like social media campaigns, creative protests, public events, and other tactics that are designed to inspire action and build momentum.

5. Strong Organizational Infrastructure: Advocacy campaigns need to have a strong organizational infrastructure to ensure that both grassroots and top-down strategies are implemented effectively. This means having a clear strategy, effective leadership, and good communication channels between all stakeholders.', 'Yes, there are many successful advocacy campaigns that have effectively balanced grassroots and top-down strategies. Here are a few examples:

1. The Marriage Equality Campaign: The campaign for marriage equality in the United States is a great example of balancing grassroots and top-down strategies. The grassroots arm of the campaign involved mobilizing volunteers and activists to spread the message of marriage equality through community outreach and social media. The top-down strategies involved lobbying national legislators and working with influential public figures to create a groundswell of support for the issue. 2. The Fight for $15: The campaign for a $15 minimum wage is another example of a successful advocacy campaign that used a combination of grassroots and top-down strategies. The grassroots arm of the campaign involved mobilizing fast food workers and other low-wage earners to demand a living wage through direct actions and protests. The top-down strategies involved working with allied organizations, policymakers, and community leaders to push for policy changes at the state and national levels. 3. The #MeToo Movement: The #MeToo movement is a powerful example of a grassroots campaign that gained momentum and support from both everyday people and high-profile figures. The campaign sparked a conversation around sexual harassment and assault, with everyday people taking to social media to share their experiences and advocate for change. The top-down strategies involved working with lawmakers, corporations, and other influential organizations to change policies and practices around sexual harassment and assault. Overall, successful advocacy campaigns balance grassroots and top-down strategies by building strong networks, collaborating with decision-makers, tailoring messaging, using creative tactics, and having strong organizational infrastructure.', 'Yes, grassroots efforts can be very effective when they are done correctly. Here are some tips for making grassroots advocacy more effective:

1. Build Strong Partnerships: Grassroots advocacy is all about building strong partnerships with like-minded organizations and individuals. Take the time to identify key allies and work collaboratively with them to help amplify your message.

2. Focus on Local Issues: Grassroots advocacy is most effective when it is focused on a specific, local issue that resonates with people in the community. Identify an issue that affects your community and work to mobilize support around that issue.

3. Use Social Media: Social media is a powerful tool for grassroots advocacy campaigns. Use social media to connect with new supporters, mobilize existing supporters, and spread your message to a wider audience.

4. Hold Public Events: Public events, such as rallies, marches, and town halls, are a great way to engage with the community and build momentum around your cause. Plan a well-organized event that is inclusive and accessible to all, and make sure to follow up with attendees to keep them engaged.

5. Empower Grassroots Leaders: Grassroots advocacy is most effective when it is led by grassroots leaders who are rooted in the community. Empower local leaders by providing them with the tools and resources they need to be effective advocates.

6. Use Data: Data can be a powerful tool for grassroots advocacy campaigns. Use data to track your progress, identify areas where you need to improve, and make the case for policy change based on the evidence.

Overall, effective grassroots advocacy involves building strong partnerships, focusing on local issues, using social media, holding public events, empowering grassroots leaders, and using data to track your progress.', "Both focusing on one specific issue and covering multiple issues have their advantages and disadvantages. Ultimately, which approach you take depends on your goals and the needs of your community. Here are some things to consider:

Focusing on One Specific Issue:
- Allows for a more targeted and focused advocacy effort, which can make it easier to mobilize support and achieve specific policy goals.
- May be easier to communicate a clear and compelling message to the public and policymakers.
- Can help establish a reputation for expertise and leadership on a particular issue.

Covering Multiple Issues:
- Allows for a broader advocacy effort, which may appeal to a wider range of people and organizations.
- Can help build broader coalitions and partnerships, which can lead to more sustained advocacy efforts.
- May be necessary if multiple issues are interrelated and need to be addressed together.

Ultimately, the decision depends on your specific goals and the needs of your community. If you are choosing to focus on one specific issue, make sure that it is an issue that resonates with your community and has the potential to make a significant impact. If you are choosing to cover multiple issues, make sure that you have a clear strategy for how you'll prioritize and balance your advocacy efforts across all of them."]

prompt_en: ['Write detailed instructions on how to make hamburger soup using ground beef, vegetables, and broth. Please include specific measurements and cooking times for each ingredient. Additionally, please provide any necessary steps for preparing and cooking the meat or vegetables. Feel free to add any optional ingredients or spices to enhance the flavor.', "Wow, thank you so much for these detailed instructions on how to make hamburger soup! I can't wait to try it. However, could you please tell me a bit more about the amount of time it takes to prepare and cook the vegetables? Also, I'm interested in any variations that may give the soup a different flavor profile.", 'Could you please suggest some more ideas on how to make this hamburger soup a bit healthier? Maybe some alternative ingredients that are lower in calories or fat?']
response_en:
['Ingredients:
- 1 pound ground beef
- 1 onion, chopped
- 4 garlic cloves, minced
- 4 cups beef broth
- 2 cups diced potatoes
- 1 cup diced carrots
- 1 cup diced celery
- 1 can diced tomatoes (14.5 oz)
- 1 teaspoon dried thyme
- 1 teaspoon dried oregano
- 1 teaspoon paprika
- 1 teaspoon salt
- 1/2 teaspoon black pepper

Instructions:
1. In a large soup pot, brown the ground beef over medium heat, breaking it up into small pieces with a wooden spoon or spatula. Cook until browned and cooked through, about 8-10 minutes.
2. Using a slotted spoon, remove the ground beef from the pot and transfer to a plate. Discard any excess fat from the pot.
3. In the same pot, sauté the chopped onion over medium heat until translucent, about 3-4 minutes. Add the minced garlic and cook for another minute.
4. Add the beef broth, diced potatoes, carrots, celery, diced tomatoes, dried thyme, dried oregano, paprika, salt, and black pepper to the pot. Stir to combine.
5. Bring the soup to a boil, then reduce the heat and let it simmer for 20-25 minutes, until the vegetables are tender.
6. Add the cooked ground beef back into the pot and stir.
7. Taste the soup and adjust seasonings as needed.
8. Serve hot and enjoy!

Optional additions:
- 1 cup frozen peas or corn
- 1 cup chopped kale or spinach
- 1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce
- 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper for a spicy kick

Notes:
- You can also use chicken broth or vegetable broth instead of beef broth.
- If you want to make this soup in a slow cooker, cook the ground beef and sauté the onion and garlic in a separate pan, then add all ingredients to the slow cooker and cook on low for 6-8 hours.', 'Of course! The cooking time for the vegetables will depend on the size of the diced pieces. I recommend cutting them into small, bite-sized pieces so that they cook through quicker. As a general rule, the potatoes and carrots will take the longest to soften, so you may want to start with those and then add the celery towards the end.

As for variations, you can certainly adjust the seasonings to your liking. Here are a few ideas:

- Italian-style: Instead of thyme and oregano, use Italian seasoning blend and add a can of cannellini beans for extra protein and fiber. Top with Parmesan cheese before serving.
- Mexican-style: Add a can of black beans, a can of corn, and a diced jalapeño pepper for some spicy heat. Top with avocado, cilantro, and a squeeze of lime.
- Asian-style: Use chicken broth instead of beef broth and add a tablespoon of grated ginger and a tablespoon of soy sauce. Top with green onions and sesame seeds.
- Mediterranean-style: Add a can of chickpeas, some chopped Kalamata olives, and feta cheese. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle with chopped parsley.', "Certainly! Here are some ideas for making this hamburger soup a bit healthier:

- Swap the ground beef for ground turkey or chicken. These meats are leaner and lower in fat and calories. - Use low-sodium broth to reduce the amount of sodium in the soup. - Replace the potatoes with sweet potatoes or butternut squash. These vegetables are lower in calories and higher in fiber and nutrients. - Add more vegetables, such as zucchini, bell peppers, or green beans. These will add flavor and nutrition to the soup without adding a lot of calories. - Use herbs and spices to add flavor instead of salt or high-calorie ingredients. For example, use fresh herbs like basil or parsley, or add spices like cumin or coriander. - Use a cooking spray or a small amount of oil to brown the beef and sauté the vegetables instead of using a lot of oil or butter. By making a few substitutions and tweaks, you can make this hamburger soup a healthier option that's still delicious and satisfying!"]

prompt_en: ["How has Scotland's history of shipbuilding and seafaring influenced its cultural identity, particularly in the coastal communities of Aberdeen and the Shetland Islands?", "Wow, it's fascinating to learn about the deep connection Scotland has with the sea. How has the decline of shipbuilding and seafaring affected the cultural identity of these coastal communities?", "It's sad to think that the decline of these industries could lead to the loss of such an important part of Scotland's cultural heritage. Is there anything being done to preserve these traditions and pass them on to future generations?"]
response_en:
["Scotland's history of shipbuilding and seafaring has had a significant impact on its cultural identity, particularly in the coastal communities of Aberdeen and the Shetland Islands. These areas have a rich maritime history that dates back centuries, and the seafaring traditions and shipbuilding skills have been passed down from generation to generation.

For example, Aberdeen has a long history of shipbuilding, with shipyards dating back to the 14th century. This industry has played a significant role in shaping the city's identity and economy, and the seafaring traditions are deeply ingrained in the local culture. Aberdeen is also home to the Aberdeen Maritime Museum, which highlights the city's maritime heritage and the important role that the sea has played in the development of the region.

Similarly, the Shetland Islands have a strong connection to the sea, and the islanders have been involved in seafaring for centuries. The islands' location between Scotland and Norway has made them an important hub for trade and fishing, and their maritime heritage is reflected in the local customs and traditions. For example, the annual Up Helly Aa festival, which takes place in various parts of Shetland, celebrates the Norse heritage of the islands and involves a parade of Viking longships.

Overall, Scotland's history of shipbuilding and seafaring has played a significant role in shaping its cultural identity, particularly in coastal communities like Aberdeen and the Shetland Islands. The skills and traditions associated with these industries have been passed down through generations, and they continue to influence the local culture and way of life.", "The decline of shipbuilding and seafaring has had a significant impact on the cultural identity of Scotland's coastal communities. The loss of these industries has meant that many of the skills and traditions associated with shipbuilding and seafaring are no longer being passed down through the generations. This has led to a sense of loss and nostalgia among the people who were once involved in these industries.

In Aberdeen, for example, the decline of shipbuilding has led to a shift in the city's economy towards the oil and gas industry. While this has brought new opportunities, it has also meant that the city's maritime heritage has become less prominent in the local culture. The Aberdeen Maritime Museum continues to celebrate the city's maritime history, but many of the people who once worked in the shipyards have moved on to other industries.

Similarly, in the Shetland Islands, the decline of seafaring has had a significant impact on the local culture. While fishing and other sea-based industries still play a role in the islands' economy, many young people are leaving to seek opportunities on the mainland. This has led to a decline in the number of people who are involved in traditional sea-based industries, and the cultural traditions associated with these industries may be in danger of being lost.

Overall, the decline of shipbuilding and seafaring has had a profound impact on Scotland's coastal communities. While these industries may no longer be as prominent as they once were, the cultural heritage and traditions associated with them continue to be an important part of Scotland's identity.", "Yes, there are efforts being made to preserve Scotland's maritime heritage and pass on the traditions associated with shipbuilding and seafaring to future generations. These efforts take many forms, including the preservation of historic ships and buildings, the establishment of museums and educational programs, and the promotion of cultural events and festivals.

In Aberdeen, for example, the Aberdeen Maritime Museum is an important hub for the preservation of the city's maritime heritage. The museum showcases the history of shipbuilding and seafaring in the region, and provides educational programs for local schools and visitors. Additionally, there are several events and festivals throughout the year that celebrate the city's maritime heritage, such as the Scottish Traditional Boat Festival and the Portsoy Boat Festival.

Similarly, in the Shetland Islands, efforts are being made to preserve the islands' seafaring traditions. The Shetland Museum and Archives is a popular destination for visitors and locals alike, offering exhibitions and events that showcase the islands' rich history and culture. The Up Helly Aa festival, which takes place annually in various parts of the islands, is another important cultural event that celebrates the islands' seafaring heritage.

Overall, while the decline of shipbuilding and seafaring has had a significant impact on Scotland's coastal communities, there are ongoing efforts to preserve these traditions and pass them on to future generations. By promoting education and cultural events, these communities hope to keep their maritime heritage alive and ensure that it remains an important part of Scotland's cultural identity."]

prompt_en:
["Read the passage below and answer the question or follow the instruction: How has Bazzi's North American tour been going so far, and what is the most memorable experience he has had with a fan during the tour?

Passage: Snapchat might be falling out of favor, but Bazzi’s career is just getting started.
Earlier this year, the pop/R&B newcomer scored a viral hit on the headline-making app with breakthrough single “Mine,” a slinky, love-struck confessional that rocketed to No. 11 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, and has amassed more than 225,000 streams on Spotify. It’s featured on his debut album, “Cosmic,” released last week.
In between playing shows and games of “NBA 2K” on his Xbox, the 20-year-old (full name: Andrew Bazzi) told us 10 things you should know about him.
Before the North American tour, which launched last week, “she gave me cupcakes and wrote me the sweetest letter.” His favorite song from the “Havana” hit-maker: her current single, “Never Be the Same.” “It’s just so good. It’s a very nostalgic song and feels like a classic.” The duo performs Sunday at the Riviera Theatre in Chicago.
“I’ve been playing guitar since I was 6, and then drums, bass and piano since I was 10 years old.” He plays instruments on all of “Cosmic’s” 16 tracks.", "Can you tell me how Bazzi's tour has been going so far and if he has shared any memorable fan experiences?", 'Can you remind me of Bazzi's favorite song from the "Havana" hit-maker and where he and Camila Cabello will be performing together?']
response_en: ['What is the name of Bazzi\'s debut album? \n\nThe name of Bazzi\'s debut album is "Cosmic."', "The article mentions that Bazzi's North American tour had launched last week before the article was written, so there is no update on how the tour is going so far. The article also does not mention any memorable fan experiences during the tour.", 'Bazzi\'s favorite song from the "Havana" hit-maker is her current single, "Never Be the Same." The article also mentions that Bazzi and Camila Cabello will be performing together at the Riviera Theatre in Chicago.']

prompt_en:
["What are the artist's thoughts on the location of their work and how it affects the temporality and purpose of the artwork?
Generate according to: The expanded field of painting can be basically described as forms of painting that go beyond Greenbergian notions of flatness. Paintings that specifically challenge that flatness as part of their creation and form.
My work has fallen into the expanded field of painting for the last two years, and although the definition is becoming somewhat different, I still find myself identifying with the category.
I have covered the reasons that I use installation in another reflection (one relating to mediums).
“ Exploring my questions and interests in a more expanded field, installation allows the space the pieces are shown in to become the surface, a literal expanded field.
The audience is a consideration throughout the creation of these works, but again that can arguably be said for many artworks.
Bringing the audience into more of a direct, or influential, dialogue with the works is something I am currently exploring. (Through motion capture, responsive technologies and audience restrictions).
Embodiment here is related to the experience of the viewer (as stated above and below) but I feel a note should be made to the embodiment of materials or ideas. Embodiment is somewhat tied to objectification, although in a more positive light. This link is something I would like to continue in the future, especially the more I realise the importance of the word ‘objectification’.
It is the embodiment of audience, through a careful consideration of spatial concerns, that drives my work towards installation. Spatial concerns are arguably prevalent in all art, however space is moving more towards the subject area of my practice.
The location of the work is a subject I've been thinking about alot lately. My work exists in my studio and I am unsure if it could live outside of it. I have been both encouraged and discouraged to take my work outside the studio, and I'll admit to being unsure where I would take it.
However location, especially in terms of gallery and studio, is a term I find interesting in its temporality. Locations are mostly imposed, their are temporary, and their purpose fluctuates.
In terms of my practice the term is one that is on hold somewhat at the moment. While I attempt to explore the ‘right’ location for my practice and its outputs.
I find myself concluding, once more, that these are useful descriptive words and ideas but not a focus. They border on mediums rather than concepts or drives.
The shift out of the studio is an important point.", 'Can you provide me some insights on how the location of the artwork can affect its reception from the audience?']
response_en:
["It challenges the notion of the artwork's temporality and purpose, as the location can add a different layer of meaning and context to the piece. The purpose of the artwork may shift depending on where it is displayed and how it interacts with its surroundings. The location can also affect how long the artwork is able to exist, as temporary spaces may only allow for a limited time to display the work. As an artist in the expanded field of painting, the location of my work is an important consideration that can influence the overall concept and impact of the artwork.", "Certainly! The location of an artwork can have a significant impact on how it is received by the audience. Here are some insights:

1. Gallery vs. Public space: Artworks displayed in a gallery are often viewed within a specific context and setting, which can frame how the audience perceives the artwork. In contrast, artworks displayed in a public space can be more accessible to a wider range of viewers, but may require different considerations, such as how the artwork interacts with its surroundings and how it is cared for.

2. Size of the space: The scale of the location can also impact the audience's experience of the artwork. For example, if an artwork is displayed in a large space, it may appear smaller or less impactful than if it were displayed in a smaller space.

3. Lighting: Lighting can greatly affect the way an artwork is perceived. Bright lighting can enhance the colors and details of the artwork, while dim lighting can create a more subdued mood.

4. Proximity to other artworks: The location of the artwork in relation to other artworks can also affect its reception by the audience. If an artwork is displayed in close proximity to other works, it may be viewed as part of a larger exhibition and considered in comparison to other artworks.

5. Cultural and historical significance: Artworks that are displayed in locations with cultural or historical significance can take on added layers of meaning, as they may be viewed in relation to the location's history or cultural context.

Overall, the location of the artwork is an important aspect to consider as it can affect how the artwork is perceived by the audience and contribute to its overall impact."]

prompt_en: ['Develop a Java program with proper commenting and formatting guidelines that can perform an iterative binary search on a given array of integers. The program should include error handling to handle cases such as invalid input and empty arrays.', 'Could you add some comments to the `binarysearch` method to explain how the search algorithm works?', 'However, could you also add a comment explaining how the search algorithm takes advantage of the fact that the array is sorted in ascending order?', "Your comments on the `binarysearch` method are really helpful! is there any way you can add some code to handle the case where the user enters an empty array? I just want to make sure the program doesn't crash if that happens."]

['Jo Arden is head of strategy at 23red and a passionate advocate of the good that marketing can do, working on social purpose and behaviour change projects for the past 10 years.
It seems appropriate on the day that the IPA launches both Effectiveness Week and the 2016 IPA Effectiveness Award shortlist, to reflect on the topic more generally and to think about some of the key challenges we face today as marketers.
This year there is a new edge to the conversation. It feels like there is an urgency to get serious about effectiveness and to build a common structure into our discipline. This has no doubt been driven in some part by the importance of marketing in a world where we have seen a major switch in the make-up of many balance sheets in terms of the proportion of tangible and intangible assets.
Determining exactly what contribution marketing makes to those intangible assets takes some unpicking but clearly there is a significant contribution across the marketing mix. This is particularly so in the new economies which are heavily built on service connection or sharing and where the business itself owns very little in physical terms but enormous amounts in terms of brand equity, relationships and data.
There is ever more granular data becoming readily available via social monitoring which can help determine the performance of some channels in some campaigns. These measures are interesting and can help build a patchwork understanding when used together. But they need to be treated with extreme caution. It’s not so long ago that we thought Facebook likes were a magic barometer of consumer engagement. There are solid measures that will remain solid amid the vagaries of social measurement and we need to protect them whilst still taking what we can from more opportunistic indicators.
Econometrics is an astoundingly good way to understand effectiveness and to build a platform for continued improvement. But they can feel like a luxury: they are complex and investment-heavy and for many smaller brands that investment can seem out of kilter with the marketing budget as a whole. Perhaps we can unlock some of the thinking and the processes that are the foundations of econometrics to allow marketing directors with smaller budgets (not forgetting the utility first, marketing later model of many startups means that these could be our Ubers of tomorrow) to build discipline and rigour into measurement from day one.
It may be counter-intuitive in this context to make a call to protect that which can’t be measured too. There are cases where all evidence points to a course of action, or where intuition has to prevail and we need to be careful to take these chances even where we know measurement is thin. Measuring success only after the event used to be the norm and some brave and ultimately successful work ran as a result.
Effectiveness and the ability of all of us who work in this diverse and dynamic field to measure it will in turn allow us common of much more business led conversations. But this is not a one-way journey. Businesses models have changed and with that the conversations which we all need to build successful brands have changed too. Reframing effectiveness as a business critical topic, rather than a justification of marketing, means moving forward collaboratively. Besides, it’s at the heart of what we do to want to deliver what audiences need and the audience we most need to engage now is the boardroom. Based on the passage above, How has the conversation about marketing effectiveness shifted from being a justification for marketing to a business critical topic as business models have changed?', 'Can you provide some examples of solid measures that remain unchanged even with the vagaries of social measurement?', 'How can smaller brands with limited budgets incorporate discipline and rigor into their measurement processes?']
response_en: ['As business models have changed, the conversation about marketing effectiveness has shifted from being a justification for marketing to a business critical topic. This is because there has been a major switch in the make-up of many balance sheets in terms of the proportion of tangible and intangible assets. Determining the exact contribution of marketing to those intangible assets requires a common structure and discipline in our discipline. It has become urgent to get serious about effectiveness and build a common structure into our discipline. This will allow us to have more business-led conversations and engage the boardroom, which is the audience we most need to engage now. Reframing effectiveness as a business critical topic means moving forward collaboratively.', 'Solid measures that remain unchanged even with the vagaries of social measurement include sales data, website traffic, conversion rates, and customer retention rates. These metrics provide a direct link between marketing efforts and business outcomes and are less prone to fluctuation due to changes in social media algorithms and user behavior. However, these metrics should also be considered in the context of the overall marketing mix and should not be relied on in isolation.', 'Smaller brands with limited budgets can incorporate discipline and rigor into their measurement processes by focusing on using data that are readily available, such as web analytics, social media analytics, and customer feedback. They can start by setting clear goals and objectives for their marketing campaigns and identifying the key performance indicators (KPIs) that will help measure success. Once the KPIs have been identified, they can establish a regular reporting process to track progress and identify areas for improvement. They can also consider using free or low-cost tools such as Google Analytics, Hootsuite, or SurveyMonkey to help with data collection and analysis. By adopting a disciplined and data-driven approach to measurement, even smaller brands can make informed decisions about their marketing strategies and optimize their ROI.']

prompt_en: ['Develop a comprehensive content marketing plan for a nonprofit organization that includes strategies for creating and promoting engaging and valuable content through various channels, such as social media, email marketing, and blogs. The plan should also identify key metrics for measuring the success of the content marketing initiatives and outline a budget for the implementation of the plan. Additionally, the plan should consider the audience, objectives, tone, and voice of the nonprofit organization to ensure the content is aligned with its mission and values.', 'This content marketing plan looks great so far! Can you add some more information on how the nonprofit can measure the effectiveness of their email marketing campaign?', "That's really helpful information. Can you also give some tips on how to write effective subject lines for email campaigns?"]
response_en:
["Introduction:

Content marketing is the process of creating and distributing valuable, relevant, and consistent content to attract and retain a clearly defined audience – with the ultimate goal of driving profitable customer action. It’s an essential component of any effective marketing strategy, and the nonprofit sector is no exception. 

Nonprofit organizations rely heavily on content marketing to engage with their target audiences, build awareness of their causes and ultimately achieve their mission. A comprehensive content marketing plan will help a nonprofit organization build a loyal following, increase website traffic, boost engagement, and ultimately drive more donations or volunteer support. 

In this article, we will develop a comprehensive content marketing plan for a nonprofit organization that includes the following components: 

- Objectives 
- Target audience 
- Content creation strategy 
- Content distribution strategy
- Key success metrics 
- Budget 

Objectives:

Before developing a content marketing plan, it’s important to identify your organization's key objectives. What is your nonprofit trying to accomplish with your content marketing efforts? Some common objectives for nonprofit organizations are: 

- Increase awareness of the organization and its mission 
- Increase engagement with target audiences 
- Build a loyal following 
- Drive donations or volunteer support 
- Increase social media following 
- Drive traffic to a website 

Target Audience:

Now that you’ve identified your organization's objectives, it’s time to identify your target audience. Who are you trying to reach with your content marketing efforts? Understanding your target audience is critical to creating content that resonates with them. 

Your target audience may be segmented into different groups based on age, gender, location, interests, and behaviors. For example, if your nonprofit works to end homelessness, your primary audience might be young, urban-dwelling millennials who are passionate about social justice issues. 

Content Creation Strategy:

The next step in creating a comprehensive content marketing plan is to develop a content creation strategy. Your content should be engaging, valuable, and consistent, and aligned with your nonprofit organization's mission and values. 

Your nonprofit organization's content creation strategy should consider the following: 

- Tone and voice: The tone and voice of your nonprofit's content should reflect the mission and values of your organization. It should be consistent across all channels and content types. 
- Content types: There are many different types of content that your nonprofit can create, including blog posts, infographics, videos, podcasts, and e-books. 
- Content themes and topics: Your nonprofit's content theme should be aligned with your organization's mission and values. You should also consider what content topics will be most engaging for your target audience. 
- Content creation schedule: Creating an editorial calendar will help you plan your content creation schedule and ensure that you're creating content consistently. 

Content Distribution Strategy:

Creating valuable content is only the first step in a successful content marketing plan. Your nonprofit's content must be distributed effectively to reach your target audience. There are many channels available for content distribution, including email marketing, social media, and blogs. 

Your content distribution strategy should include the following: 

- Email marketing: Email marketing is an effective way to reach your nonprofit's supporters and keep them informed about your organization's activities. Your nonprofit can use email marketing to share newsletters, event invitations, or fundraising appeals. 
- Social media: Social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and LinkedIn are great ways to share your nonprofit's content with a broader audience. Social media is an excellent way to build a community around your organization and engage with your target audience. 
- Blogging: Your nonprofit's blog is an essential platform for sharing thought leadership content, sharing success stories, and promoting events or campaigns. 

Key Success Metrics:

Measuring the success of your nonprofit's content marketing initiatives is critical in determining whether your content marketing plan is effective. To measure success, it's essential to identify key metrics that align with your nonprofit's objectives. 

Some metrics that your nonprofit may consider tracking include: 

- Website traffic 
- Engagement: likes, shares, comments, and follows on social media 
- Email open and click-through rates 
- Conversion rates: donations or volunteer sign-ups 
- Content reach and frequency 

Budget:

To implement a successful content marketing plan, your nonprofit may need to invest in some resources. Your budget should include costs associated with content creation, such as software, equipment, and personnel. It should also account for costs associated with content distribution, such as advertising and email marketing software. 

Conclusion: 

A comprehensive content marketing plan is essential for any nonprofit organization looking to effectively communicate their mission and values to their target audience. By developing a content creation and distribution strategy that aligns with the nonprofit's vision, target audience, and objectives, nonprofits can build a loyal following and drive social change. Additionally, regularly tracking key metrics can help identify areas of improvement and ensure that the content marketing plan is effective.", "Sure! Measuring the effectiveness of your nonprofit's email marketing campaign is crucial to identify what’s working and what isn’t. Here are some key metrics that can help you measure the effectiveness of your email marketing campaign:

1. Open rates: This metric tells you how many of your email subscribers opened your email. You can calculate open rates by dividing the number of email opens by the number of emails delivered. A higher open rate means that your email subject lines are working well, and the content inside the email is of interest to your audience.

2. Click-through rates: This metric tells you how many people clicked on the links within the email. You can calculate click-through rates by dividing the number of clicks by the number of emails delivered. This metric measures the level of engagement of your audience and their interest in the content you’re sharing. A higher click-through rate means that the content is engaging enough, and the call-to-action is clear.

3. Conversion rates: This metric tells you how many people took the desired action after clicking on a link in your email. This action could be a donation, volunteer sign-up or any other call-to-action. You can calculate conversion rates by dividing the number of people who completed the action by the number of clicks. This metric is a direct measure of the effectiveness of your email marketing campaigns in driving the desired actions.

4. Unsubscribe rate: This metric tells you how many subscribers opted out of receiving your emails. It gives insight into whether your content resonated with your subscribers or not. A higher unsubscribe rate means that your content was not engaging enough or you’re sending too many emails.

By tracking these key metrics regularly, your nonprofit can identify the areas of weakness and what’s working to improve the effectiveness of your email marketing campaign.", 'Of course! Writing an effective subject line for your nonprofit's email campaigns is crucial to get your subscribers to open and engage with your content. Here are some tips to write effective subject lines:

1. Keep it short and sweet: Your subject line should be short and to the point, ideally around 50 characters or less. This will ensure that your entire subject line is visible on the recipient's mobile device, which is where most people read their emails.

2. Be concise and specific: Your subject line should clearly and concisely communicate the content of your email. Be specific and mention the main benefit or value proposition you're offering to the reader.

3. Use personalization: Personalization is an effective way to capture the attention of your subscribers. You can include their name or other personal information in the subject line to make it more relevant and appealing.

4. Create a sense of urgency: Adding a sense of urgency to your subject line can help increase open rates. You can use phrases like "limited time offer" or "last chance" to create a sense of urgency.

5. A/B testing: A/B testing is an effective way to test which subject line resonates more with your audience. With A/B testing, you send out two versions of the same email with different subject lines to a small percentage of your subscriber list. You can then see which subject line gets the highest open rate and use that for the rest of your list.

6. Avoid spam trigger words: Avoid using words or phrases that email providers consider spammy, like "free," "deal," or "discount." This can hurt your email deliverability and prevent your message from reaching the recipient's inbox.

By following these tips and writing compelling subject lines, your nonprofit can increase the open rates of your email campaigns and get more engagement from your subscribers.']

prompt_en: ['Please create a comprehensive pricing guide for all of your products that includes the cost of each item, suggested retail price, and any discounts or promotions currently available. The guide should be visually appealing and easy to navigate, and should also include information about any additional fees or taxes that may apply. Please utilize a professional and consistent style throughout the guide, and ensure that all information is accurate and up-to-date.', 'Can you please add some examples of value-added services that I can include in my pricing guide?']
response_en:
["I don't have any products of my own. However, as a general guideline, here are some tips for creating a comprehensive pricing guide for your products:

1. List all of your products with their respective costs.

2. Suggest the retail price for each product.

3. Include any discounts or promotions currently available for each product.

4. Include information about any additional fees or taxes that may apply.

5. Utilize a professional and consistent style throughout the guide.

6. Ensure that all information is accurate and up-to-date.

7. Use tables or charts to make the pricing guide easy to navigate.

8. Include product images to make it visually appealing.

9. Highlight the benefits of each product.

10. Explain any value-added services that come with the product.

11. Provide reviews or testimonials to establish credibility.

12. Offer a comparison with competitors' products.

13. Include a call-to-action to encourage customers to make a purchase.

14. Provide a clear and concise refund or return policy.

15. Make the pricing guide readily available on your website or in your physical store.", "Sure! Here are some examples of value-added services that you can include in your pricing guide:

1. Free delivery or shipping
2. Extended warranties
3. 24/7 customer support
4. Free installation or setup services
5. Personalization or customization services
6. Free trials or demos
7. Training sessions
8. Loyalty programs or rewards
9. Referral bonuses or discounts
10. Bundling or package deals
11. Access to exclusive content or resources
12. Complimentary maintenance or repair services. Remember to mention these services in your pricing guide as it can influence customers' decision-making process and potentially increase your sales."]

prompt_en: ["How does HubSpot's Marketing Hub help companies attract and engage customers through inbound marketing campaigns?: HubSpot is a leading growth platform. Since 2006, HubSpot has been on a mission to make the world more inbound. Today, over 52,000 total customers in more than 100 countries use HubSpotâ€™s award-winning software, services, and support to transform the way they attract, engage, and delight customers. Comprised of Marketing Hub, Sales Hub, Service Hub, and a powerful free CRM, HubSpot gives companies the tools they need to Grow Better. HubSpot Marketing Hub has everything you need to run successful inbound marketing campaigns that make people interested in your business and happy to be your customer.\nIf youâ€™re producing effective inbound marketing content, youâ€™re generating a steady flow of new, organic leads, and youâ€™re ready to scale your successful efforts, chances are itâ€™s time to focus your efforts on a marketing automation strategy that will nurture those quality leads into paying customers. Below are some good questions to ask yourself when deciding if marketing automation is the right move for your business.", "Hey! Can you show me how to set up lead nurturing workflows using HubSpot's Marketing Hub?", "That's really helpful! Can you also show me how to use HubSpot's lead scoring feature to prioritize my leads?"]
response_en:
["1. Are you generating a steady flow of new, organic leads through inbound marketing efforts?
2. Do you have a strategy to nurture those leads and move them through your sales funnel?
3. Are you struggling to keep up with the amount of leads and effectively follow up with each one?
4. Do you want to personalize your marketing efforts and tailor them to specific audiences?
5. Are you looking for ways to improve your marketing ROI and track the success of your campaigns?
HubSpot's Marketing Hub can help with all of these challenges by providing powerful marketing automation tools, lead nurturing workflows, lead scoring, personalized content recommendations, and advanced analytics and reporting. With Marketing Hub, you can optimize your marketing efforts and grow your business through effective inbound marketing campaigns that attract, engage, and delight your customers.", 'Sure, I'd be happy to help you set up lead nurturing workflows in HubSpot's Marketing Hub. Here's a step-by-step guide:

1. Go to your HubSpot dashboard and click on the "Workflows" tab.
2. Click on "Create Workflow".
3. Choose the "Start from scratch" option and click "Select".
4. Give your workflow a name and select the "Contact Workflow" type.
5. Choose the trigger that will start the workflow. This can be based on a specific action a contact takes, such as filling out a form or downloading an ebook, or it can be based on a set date or time.
6. Add any additional enrollment triggers based on contact properties or behaviors.
7. Next, add a series of actions that will be performed when a contact is enrolled in the workflow. This could include sending a welcome email, educational content, product information and more. 
8. Set a delay between each email or content offer.
9. Use conditions to personalize your messaging based on specific actions your contacts take. For example, if they show interest in a certain product, you can send them more information about that product.
10. Use lead scoring to prioritize leads for sales outreach based on their engagement level.
11. Create a goal that will end the workflow when a contact reaches a certain stage or behavior, such as becoming a customer or unsubscribing from emails.

That's it! By following these steps, you can create a customized lead nurturing workflow that will help you engage and convert more leads into customers.', 'Absolutely! Here's how to use HubSpot's lead scoring feature:

1. Go to your HubSpot dashboard and click on the "Contacts" tab.
2. Click on the "Properties" tab and scroll down to the "Lead Scoring" section.
3. Click "Create a New Property".
4. Name your property and select "Number" as the field type.
5. Set the initial value for your property based on the actions a contact may take on your site or in your marketing campaigns.
6. Set up individual scoring criteria and assign point values to each. These criteria could include web page views, time spent on site, email opens, email clicks, form submissions or any other behavior that indicates a lead's level of engagement and interest.
7. Customize your scoring criteria based on the goals of your business and the types of leads you're looking to prioritize. For example, you may want to assign more points to leads who visit your pricing page or who download an ebook.
8. Use negative scoring options to subtract points when leads take actions that suggest disinterest or lack of quality, such as unsubscribing from emails or never engaging with your content.
9. Based on the total score, create lists of prioritized leads for your sales team to follow up on, or use the lead score as a qualification factor for your marketing campaigns.

That's it! By using HubSpot's lead scoring feature, you can efficiently prioritize leads and focus your efforts on those who are most likely to convert into customers.']

prompt_en: ['Can you explain the different levels within the Royal Victorian Order and what criteria are used to determine the appropriate level for an individual?', 'Wow, I had no idea there were so many levels within the Royal Victorian Order! Do you know of any famous people who have received one of these awards?', "That's really interesting! I had no idea that foreign dignitaries could receive the Grand Cross level of the Royal Victorian Order. Do you know of any examples of this happening?", "Wow, it's fascinating to learn about all the different people who have received the Royal Victorian Order, both British and foreign. Do you know if anyone has ever received multiple levels of the Order?"]
response_en:
["The Royal Victorian Order (RVO) was founded by Queen Victoria in 1896 as a way to recognize personal service to the Monarchy. It consists of five levels, listed here in ascending order of prestige:

1. Member (MVO): This is the lowest level of the RVO and is awarded for personal service to the Monarch, or to a member of the Royal Family. Criteria for this award include a minimum of five years of service, or significant contributions made in a shorter period of time.

2. Lieutenant (LVO): This level is awarded for a minimum of ten years of meritorious service to the Monarch or Royal Family, or for special contributions to the arts, sciences, or charitable work.

3. Commander (CVO): The third level of the RVO is awarded for a minimum of fifteen years of meritorious service to the Monarch, Royal Family, or Commonwealth. This level may also be given for important contributions to public life or for special achievement in artistic or charitable fields.

4. Knight or Dame Commander (KCVO/DCVO): The fourth level of the RVO is reserved for those who have made exceptional contributions to the Monarch, Royal Family, or Commonwealth. This level may also be given for exceptional achievement in arts, sciences, or charitable work.

5. Knight or Dame Grand Cross (GCVO): This is the highest level of the RVO and is awarded only to those who have achieved significant distinction in their service to the Monarch, Royal Family, or Commonwealth. It is also occasionally given to foreign dignitaries who have made important contributions to British interests.

Overall, the criteria for each level of the RVO are subjective and based on the individual's level of service or achievement, as well as their perceived value to the Monarchy or the Commonwealth. Award recipients may be nominated by government officials, members of the Royal Family, or other notable individuals.", 'Yes, many notable individuals have received the Royal Victorian Order over the years. Here are just a few examples:

- Sir Elton John was made a Knight Commander (KCVO) in 1998 for his charitable work and contributions to music.
- Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the late U.S. Supreme Court Justice, was awarded the Knight Commander (KBE) in 2019 for her contributions to the law and promoting gender equality.
- Angela Lansbury, the actress best known for her role in the TV series "Murder, She Wrote," was awarded the Dame Commander (DBE) in 2014 for her contributions to drama.
- Nobel Prize-winning author Kazuo Ishiguro was awarded the Knight Bachelor (KN) in 2018 for his contributions to literature.
- Olympian Jessica Ennis-Hill was made a Dame Commander (DBE) in 2017 for her contributions to athletics and service to the community.

These are just a few examples, and there are many other famous individuals who have received the Royal Victorian Order.', 'Yes, it is not uncommon for foreign dignitaries to receive the Grand Cross level of the Royal Victorian Order. Here are a few examples:

- In 2019, the King of Bahrain, Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa, was awarded the Knight Grand Cross (GCVO) for his work in promoting international relations.
- In 2018, the King of Spain, Felipe VI, was awarded the Knight Grand Cross (GCVO) during his state visit to the UK.
- In 2017, the President of Ireland, Michael D. Higgins, was awarded the Knight Grand Cross (GCVO) for his contributions to Anglo-Irish relations.
- In 2013, the President of Germany, Joachim Gauck, was awarded the Knight Grand Cross (GCVO) for his work promoting German-British relations.

These are just a few examples, but there have been many other foreign dignitaries who have been awarded the Grand Cross level of the Royal Victorian Order over the years.', 'Yes, there are a few individuals who have received multiple levels of the Royal Victorian Order. Here are some examples:

- Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, was awarded the Knight Grand Cross (GCVO) in 1953 and later promoted to Knight Grand Cross and Knight Grand Cross with Collar (GCVO and GCVO/PC), the latter being the highest rank, in 1971 and 2017, respectively.
- Queen Elizabeth II was awarded the Grand Cross (GCVO) in 1953 and later promoted to Grand Master (GCMG) in 2007, which is a separate order but also recognizes service to the Commonwealth.
- Princess Anne was awarded the Member (MVO) in 1974, promoted to Lieutenant (LVO) in 1988, Commander (CVO) in 2000 and then Knight Grand Cross (GCVO) in 2012.

These are just a few examples, but it is not uncommon for individuals to receive multiple levels of the Royal Victorian Order over the course of their lifetime, as they continue to make contributions to the Monarchy or the Commonwealth.']

prompt_en:
['INGLEWOOD — When you first come upon Environmental Charter Middle School-Inglewood while walking or driving, from the outside the campus sort of blends in with the neighborhood with its less-than-spectacular appearance.
